sections.title: Introduction (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Hey, it’s Jihad Al Sayed. Today, we’re breaking down one of the most powerful matrix transformations — diagonalization. This concept gives you superpowers when it comes to simplifying matrix computations.

sections.title: What Is Diagonalization?
sections.content: A matrix A is diagonalizable if it can be written as A = PDP⁻¹, where D is a diagonal matrix and P is a matrix of eigenvectors. This lets us raise A to powers easily.

sections.title: How to Diagonalize
sections.math:
1. Find eigenvalues: \text{det}(A - \lambda I) = 0
2. Find eigenvectors for each λ
3. Form matrix P from eigenvectors
4. D has eigenvalues on the diagonal

sections.title: Example
sections.math:
A = \begin{bmatrix}5 & 4\\1 & 2\end{bmatrix}
→ Eigenvalues: λ = 6, 1
→ Eigenvectors: v₁, v₂
→ A = PDP⁻¹ with D = diag(6, 1)

sections.title: Why It Matters
sections.content: Diagonal matrices are super easy to work with. You can compute Aⁿ just by computing Dⁿ. This saves time in simulations, quantum systems, and dynamical models.

sections.title: Recap
sections.content: We explored how diagonalization works, how to compute it, and why it drastically simplifies working with matrices. It’s a must-know for efficient matrix operations.
